p: Observational studies of the San Francisco iART experience identified outcome disparities between subgroups. Follow-up of the RAPID cohort did show that 95% maintained viral suppression at 1 year [ 25]. However, as this approach was adopted by the entire city of San Francisco, a recent evaluation of citywide RAPID outcomes demonstrated that some groups, including Latinx patients, were more likely to initiate iART at first visit, while transgender women were least likely to initiate iART at first visit [ 26]. There were also emerging disparities in time to first viral suppression among people who inject drugs and African Americans [ 26]. The signal of emerging disparities highlighted by this study calls for an evaluation of what key elements need to be added to the RAPID model to better serve the most vulnerable populations with HIV.
